prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
stories:
A toddler was rushed to the hospital after nearly drowning in a wave pool at a popular waterpark on Saturday.

The three-year-old boy is in stable condition following the incident at SplashWorld Waterpark at around 15:30 BST, authorities said.

A 32-year-old man from Manchester, believed to be the child's father, was arrested on suspicion of child endangerment.

He has been released pending further investigation.

Insp. Rachel Patel, of the local police department, said: "Our main priority is the well-being of the young boy and his family. We urge anyone who witnessed the incident, particularly those who were in the wave pool area between 14:30 and 15:15, to come forward with any information.

"We understand that speculation can be unhelpful, and we ask that the public refrains from spreading unsubstantiated rumors about the incident. The family appreciates your respect during this difficult time."

The waterpark has issued a statement saying: "Our trained lifeguards responded quickly to the emergency and provided care until the paramedics arrived. We are cooperating fully with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the police department's non-emergency number or email tips to [tips@police.gov](mailto:tips@police.gov).

A six-year-old girl was airlifted to a trauma center after a severe allergic reaction to a food item at a bustling amusement park on Sunday afternoon.

The child, who is in critical but stable condition, was visiting FunFest Park with her family when she consumed a treat from a vendor that triggered the life-threatening response, according to eyewitnesses.

A 29-year-old woman, believed to be the girl's mother, was taken into custody on suspicion of negligence. She has been released on bail pending further investigation.

Lt. Michael Chen, of the local sheriff's department, urged anyone who witnessed the incident, particularly those who were in the vicinity of the food stalls between 13:00 and 14:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand that the public's concern is natural, but we ask that people refrain from spreading speculation about the incident. The family is grateful for your discretion during this challenging time," Lt. Chen said.

FunFest Park released a statement saying: "Our staff responded promptly to the emergency and provided care until the medical team arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the sheriff's department's tip line or email tips to [tips@sheriff.gov](mailto:tips@sheriff.gov).

A 10-year-old boy was rushed to a nearby hospital after a near-drowning incident at a crowded waterpark on Saturday morning.

The child, who is in stable condition, was swimming in the wave pool at SplashWorld with his friends when he got caught in a strong current that pulled him underwater, according to lifeguards.

A 35-year-old man, believed to be the boy's uncle, was taken into custody on suspicion of reckless endangerment. He has been released on bail pending further investigation.

Sgt. Emily Rodriguez, of the local police department, urged anyone who witnessed the incident, particularly those who were in the wave pool area between 11:00 and 12:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand that the public's concern is natural, but we ask that people refrain from spreading speculation about the incident. The family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Sgt. Rodriguez said.

SplashWorld released a statement saying: "Our lifeguards responded quickly to the emergency and provided care until the medical team arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the police department's tip line or email tips to [tips@police.gov](mailto:tips@police.gov).

A 7-year-old girl was airlifted to a trauma center after a devastating accident at a popular amusement park on Friday evening.

The child, who is listed in critical condition, was riding the spinning teacups attraction at ThrillLand with her family when she was thrown from the ride and landed on her head, according to eyewitnesses.

A 40-year-old ride operator, believed to be a 10-year veteran of the park, has been suspended pending an investigation into the incident.

Lt. James Parker, of the local sheriff's department, urged anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were in the vicinity of the spinning teacups between 8:00 and 9:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand that the public's concern is natural, but we ask that people refrain from spreading speculation about the incident. The family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Lt. Parker said.

ThrillLand released a statement saying: "Our staff responded quickly to the emergency and provided care until the medical team arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the sheriff's department's tip line or email tips to [tips@sheriff.gov](mailto:tips@sheriff.gov).

A 9-year-old boy was rushed to a nearby hospital after a terrifying incident at OceanWorld aquarium on Sunday afternoon.

The child, who is currently in stable condition, was observing the shark feeding exhibit with his classmates when a malfunctioning tank burst, showering him with glass and seawater, according to witnesses.

A 30-year-old aquarist, believed to be a 5-year veteran of the aquarium, has been placed on administrative leave pending a thorough investigation into the incident.

Sgt. Rachel Lee, of the local police department, urged anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were in the vicinity of the shark exhibit between 2:00 and 3:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand that the public's concern is natural, but we ask that people refrain from spreading speculation about the incident. The family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Sgt. Lee said.

The child, who is currently in critical but stable condition, was riding the new rollercoaster, "The Storm Chaser," with her family when a mechanical failure caused the carriage to detach, sending her plummeting 30 feet to the ground, according to eyewitnesses.

A 40-year-old ride operator, believed to be a 10-year veteran of the park, has been suspended pending a thorough investigation into the incident.

A 25-year-old professional surfer was rushed to a nearby hospital after a horrific accident at Oceanview Beach on Sunday morning.

The athlete, who remains in intensive care, was competing in the annual Surf's Up competition when a freak wave caused his leash to snap, sending him crashing into the rocky shoreline, according to bystanders.

The 35-year-old captain, who remains in intensive care, was navigating his vessel through treacherous waters when a critical mast failure sent him overboard, according to eyewitnesses on nearby boats.

A 50-year-old seasoned harbor master, a 20-year veteran of the coast, has been placed on administrative leave pending a thorough probe into the incident.

Coast Guard Investigator, Emily Sanchez, appealed to anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were in the area between 5:00 and 6:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand the public's concern, but we urge people to refrain from speculation about the incident. The sailor's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Investigator Sanchez said.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the coast guard's hotline or email tips to [tips@coastguard.gov](mailto:tips@coastguard.gov).

The 40-year-old expedition leader, who remains in critical condition, was ascending the mountain with a team of experienced climbers when a critical rope failure sent her tumbling down the icy face, according to eyewitnesses on nearby peaks.

A 60-year-old veteran mountain guide, a 30-year veteran of the mountain, has been suspended from leading expeditions pending a thorough investigation into the incident.

Mountain Rescue Team Leader, Jack Taylor, appealed to anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were in the area between 2:00 and 3:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand the public's concern, but we urge people to refrain from speculation about the incident. The mountaineer's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Team Leader Taylor said.

The 38-year-old research team leader, who remains in stable condition, was exploring the ocean floor with a crew of seasoned scientists when a critical equipment malfunction sent her plummeting into the dark abyss, according to witnesses on nearby vessels.

A 55-year-old veteran diver, a 25-year veteran of the trench, has been placed on administrative leave pending a thorough inquiry into the incident.

Marine Rescue Unit Commander, Rachel Lee, urged anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were in the area between 9:00 and 10:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand the public's concern, but we urge people to refrain from speculation about the incident. The oceanographer's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Commander Lee said.

The 42-year-old expedition leader, who remains in critical condition, was scaling the peak with a team of experienced climbers when a faulty rope anchor sent him tumbling down the rocky face, according to eyewitnesses at the base camp.

A 60-year-old veteran mountaineer, a 30-year veteran of the mountain, has been suspended from future expeditions pending a thorough investigation into the incident.

Mountain Rescue Squad Commander, James Reed, urged anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were in the area between 6:00 and 7:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand the public's concern, but we urge people to refrain from speculation about the incident. The astronomer's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Commander Reed said.

Mount Celestia officials released a statement saying: "Our response team reacted swiftly to the emergency and provided aid until the rescue helicopter arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the mountain rescue squad's hotline or email tips to [tips@mountainrescue.gov](mailto:tips@mountainrescue.gov).

A renowned oceanographer was plucked from the deck of a research vessel after a devastating experiment gone wrong in the turbulent waters of the Mariana Trench on Thursday morning.

The 38-year-old scientist, who remains in stable condition, was conducting a deep-sea dive with a team of experienced engineers when a malfunctioning submersible sent her plummeting into the dark abyss, according to crew members on the vessel.

A 50-year-old veteran marine biologist, a 25-year veteran of the research vessel, has been placed on administrative leave pending a thorough investigation into the incident.

Coast Guard Commander, Rachel Patel, urged anyone who witnessed the accident, particularly those who were on nearby vessels between 9:00 and 10:00, to come forward with any information.

"We understand the public's concern, but we urge people to refrain from speculation about the incident. The oceanographer's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Commander Patel said.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the coast guard's hotline or email tips to [tips@coastguard.gov](mailto:tips@coastguard.gov).

A celebrated astrobiologist was rescued from the frozen tundra of Antarctica after a catastrophic experiment went awry at a remote research station on Tuesday night.

The 42-year-old scientist, who is recovering from severe hypothermia, was conducting a solo expedition to collect ice core samples when a faulty generator exploded, engulfing the station in flames, according to eyewitnesses at the nearby McMurdo Station.

A 30-year-old station manager, a 10-year veteran of the Antarctic research program, has been suspended pending a thorough inquiry into the incident.

National Science Foundation Director, Dr. Maria Rodriguez, appealed to anyone who may have witnessed the accident, particularly those at nearby research camps between 8:00 and 9:00 PM, to come forward with any information.

"We understand the public's concern, but we urge people to refrain from speculation about the incident. The astrobiologist's family is grateful for your discretion during this challenging time," Dr. Rodriguez said.

McMurdo Station officials released a statement saying: "Our emergency response team responded promptly to the crisis and provided aid until the rescue team arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the NSF's hotline or email tips to [tips@nsf.gov](mailto:tips@nsf.gov).

A renowned volcanologist was airlifted from the smoldering slopes of Mount Yasur on Tanna Island after a freak accident destroyed her mobile laboratory on Wednesday morning.

The 38-year-old scientist, who is being treated for severe burns, was conducting a solo investigation into the volcano's unique lava flows when a malfunctioning drone crashed into a gas tank, sparking a massive fire, according to local guides who witnessed the incident.

A 25-year-old research assistant, a newcomer to the volcanic research program, has been placed on administrative leave pending a thorough investigation into the mishap.

Vanuatu's Minister of Environment, Mr. Kalo Pakoa, urged anyone who may have seen the accident, particularly tourists and locals in the vicinity of the volcano between 9:00 and 10:00 AM, to share any information they might have.

"We understand the public's fascination with this incident, but we request that people refrain from spreading unverified rumors. The volcanologist's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Mr. Pakoa said.

Tanna Island officials released a statement saying: "Our emergency response team responded swiftly to the crisis and provided assistance until the rescue team arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the Vanuatu Government's hotline or email tips to [tips@vanuatu.gov.vu](mailto:tips@vanuatu.gov.vu).

A celebrated marine biologist was rescued from the depths of the Mariana Trench after a catastrophic equipment failure destroyed her submersible research vessel on Friday evening.

The 42-year-old scientist, who is receiving treatment for decompression sickness, was conducting a solo expedition to study the trench's unique ecosystem when a faulty robotic arm punctured a hydraulic line, causing a rapid loss of buoyancy, according to the crew of the nearby research ship.

A 28-year-old engineer, responsible for maintaining the submersible's equipment, has been suspended pending a thorough inquiry into the disaster.

The Governor of Guam, Ms. Ana Diaz, appealed to anyone who may have witnessed the incident, particularly fishermen and sailors in the vicinity of the trench between 8:00 and 9:00 PM, to come forward with any information they might possess.

"We understand the public's fascination with this incident, but we urge people to refrain from speculating about the cause. The scientist's family is grateful for your discretion during this difficult time," Ms. Diaz said.

Guam Coast Guard officials released a statement saying: "Our response team reacted promptly to the emergency and provided assistance until the rescue vessel arrived. We are fully cooperating with the authorities and will continue to support their investigation."

Anyone with information is asked to contact the Guam Government's hotline or email tips to [tips@guam.gov.gu](mailto:tips@guam.gov.gu).

A renowned astrophysicist was airlifted to safety from the remote Atacama Desert after a devastating solar flare crippled her state-of-the-art observatory on Wednesday night.

The 38-year-old expert, who is being treated for severe burns, was leading a solo expedition to study a rare celestial event when a malfunctioning cooling system caused a catastrophic overheating of the telescope's mirrors, according to the Chilean Space Agency's rescue team.

A 25-year-old technician, responsible for maintaining the observatory's equipment, has been placed on administrative leave pending a thorough investigation into the incident.
